prompt:
Nurse: That's great. Have you gained more than 2 pounds in the past day or 5 pounds in the past week?

Patient: Nope.

Nurse: That's good to hear. Lastly, have you been using more pillows at night to sleep?

Patient: No.

Nurse: That's great. We just performed a simple CHF assessment. It's a good idea to do this at home every day. I understand that keeping track of symptoms can be complicated. Do you have any questions about how to do so?

Patient: Yeah. You asked me so many questions. How do I remember Which one? To us myself for the future.

Nurse: I understand your concern. It can be a lot to remember. One way to keep track is to write down your symptoms each day. You can use a notebook or a symptom tracker app on your phone. This can help you notice any changes over time. Would you like me to send you some resources on how to track your symptoms?

Patient: That would be lovely. I didn't know they got some some traffic there.

responses.gpt4: Absolutely, I can arrange to have some resources sent to you. Tracking your symptoms can really help you and your healthcare team notice any changes and make adjustments to your care plan if they're needed. Now, if you don't mind, I'd like to talk about your diet. Can you tell me a little bit about what you've been eating recently?
responses.our_model: Absolutely. I'll make sure to send you some resources on how to track your symptoms. Now, let's talk about your diet. Can you tell me about your recent meals?
